questions.text: Where does the initiation of nerve impulse occur in a spinal motor neuron?
questions.solution:
In a spinal motor neuron, initiation of nerve impulse occurs in the axon hillock and initial segment of the axon because it has a very high density of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels. Hence, this region is also known as the trigger zone for the action potential.

Parts of a Neuron:

  • Cell body/perikaryon: contains many Nissl bodies.
  • Dendritic zone where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated.
  • Axon hillock: part of the cell body from which the axon arises.
  • Initial segment: the first part of the axon where propagated action potentials are generated.
  • An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings. The unmyelinated regions of a myelinated axon are termed as nodes of Ranvier.
  • Synaptic knobs/nerve endings where action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters.

Note: Action potentials are generated at the initial segment in spinal motor neurons and the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons.

questions.text: Which part of the neuron contains a maximum number of Na+ channels per square micrometer?
questions.solution:
The maximum number of Na+ channels per square micrometer in myelinated neurons is present at the nodes of Ranvier. It contains 2000-12,000 channels per square micrometer.

Voltage-gated Na+ channels are highly concentrated in the nodes of Ranvier and the initial segment in myelinated neurons.

The spatial distribution of ion channels along the axon plays a key role in the initiation and regulation of action potential.

questions.text: In a cutaneous sensory neuron, at which of the following places is the propagated action potential generated?
questions.solution:
In cutaneous sensory neurons, propagated action potentials are generated in the initial node of Ranvier.

From a functional point of view, neurons generally have four important zones :

  1. A receptor, or dendritic zone, where multiple local potential changes generated by synaptic connections are integrated
  2. A site where propagated action potentials are generated (the initial segment in spinal motor neurons, the initial node of Ranvier in cutaneous sensory neurons)
  3. An axonal process that transmits propagated impulses to the nerve endings
  4. The nerve endings, where action potentials cause the release of synaptic transmitters

The cell body is often located at the dendritic zone end of the axon, but it can be within the axon (eg, auditory neurons)

questions.text: What is the relationship between diameter of the nerve and conduction velocity?
questions.solution:
The conduction velocity of a myelinated axon increases linearly with diameter.

Conduction velocity is increased by:

  • Increasing the fiber size: Increasing the diameter of a nerve fiber results in decreased internal resistance; thus, conduction velocity down the nerve is faster.

  • Myelination: Myelin acts as an insulator around nerve axons and increases conduction velocity. Myelinated nerves exhibit saltatory conduction. It is a rapid process that allows myelinated axons to conduct up to 50 times faster than the fastest unmyelinated fibers.

  • Activity of the Na+–K+ pump does not directly affect the formation or conduction of action potentials.

questions.text: What process is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3?

choices.text: Movement of Na+ into the cell
Movement of Na+ out of the cell
Movement of K+ into the cell
Movement of K+ out of the cell

questions.solution:
The graph depicts action potential. The movement of Na+ into the cell is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3.

Once the membrane is depolarized to the threshold, local potential, the upstroke of the nerve action potential is caused by the opening of the Na+ channels. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. When the Na+ channels open, Na+ moves into the cell down its electrochemical gradient, driving the membrane potential toward the Na+ equilibrium potential.

The process responsible for repolarization is the opening of K+. The K+ permeability becomes very high and drives the membrane potential toward the K+equilibrium potential by the flow of K+ out of the cell.

questions.text: The membrane conductance for potassium is maximum at which of the following points in a nerve action potential?
questions.solution:
The membrane conductance for potassium is maximum during repolarization (marked as point 3 in the above image).   

Most of the increase in K+ conductance comes after the increase in Na+ conductance around the time of repolarization. 

During the early portion of the action potential, the sodium conductance is 1000 times greater than potassium conductance. Therefore, far more sodium ions flow to the interior of the fiber than do potassium ions to the exterior. This causes the membrane potential to become positive at the action potential onset.

When the membrane potential rises from −90 millivolts toward zero, this voltage change causes a conformational change in the K+ channels which allows increased potassium efflux. Then, the sodium channels begin to close and the potassium channels begin to open, and potassium conductance begins to increase (and sodium conductance decreases).

The increased flow of K+ out of the cell causes membrane repolarization. The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state explains the after-hyperpolarization followed by a return to the resting membrane potential.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the upstroke of a nerve action potential?

choices.text: There is net outward current and the cell interior becomes more negative
There is net outward current and the cell interior becomes less negative
There is net inward current and the cell interior becomes more negative
There is net inward current and the cell interior becomes less negative

questions.solution:
Regarding the upstroke of a nerve action potential, there is a net inward current and the cell interior becomes less negative. The direction of the current is either

  1. same as the direction of positive charge ( eg, Na+ )
  2. opposite to the direction of negative charge (eg, Cl- )
  3. opposite to the direction of electrons

Since Na+ moves in, there is a net inward current.

Since the RMP increases, the cell interior becomes less negative.  

In response to a depolarizing stimulus, some of the voltage-gated Na+ channels open and Na+ enters the cell and the membrane is brought to its threshold potential. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. The rapid upstroke in the membrane potential ensues. So, there is a net influx of Na+, and the interior of the cell becomes positive during the upstroke of the action potential.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?
  Ionic Changes Components of Action Potential
1 Slow closure of voltage-gated K+ channels After-hyperpolarization
2 A decrease in extracellular Ca2+ Repolarization
3 Closing of voltage-gated Na+ channels Depolarization
4 Rapid closure of voltage-gated Na+ channels Resting membrane potential
questions.solution:
The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state also explains the after-hyperpolarization.

In response to a depolarizing stimulus, some of the voltage-gated Na+ channels open and Na+ enters the cell. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. The rapid upstroke in the membrane potential ensues.

The membrane potential moves toward the equilibrium potential for Na+ (+60 mV) but does not reach it during the action potential, primarily because the increase in Na+ conductance is short-lived. The Na+ channels rapidly enter a closed state called the inactivated state and remain in this state for a few milliseconds.

In addition, the direction of the electrical gradient for Na+ is reversed during the overshoot because the membrane potential is reversed, and this limits Na+ influx; also the voltage-gated K+ channels open. These factors contribute to repolarization. The opening of voltage-gated K+ channels is slower and more prolonged than the opening of the Na+ channels. The net movement of positive charge out of the cell due to K+ efflux at this time helps complete the process of repolarization.

The slow return of the K+ channels to the closed state also explains the after-hyperpolarization, followed by a return to the resting membrane potential.

Thus, voltage-gated K+ channels bring the action potential to an end and cause closure of their gates through a negative feedback process. 

Note: Na+ channels: Positive feedback loop; K+ channels: Negative feedback loop.

questions.text: What is known as the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus?
questions.solution:
The refractory period is the time period in which a second stronger impulse can elicit action potential after the application of one stimulus. It can be absolute or relative. 

During the rising and much of the falling phases of the spike potential, the neuron is refractory to stimulation. This refractory period is divided into an

  • Absolute refractory period, corresponding to the period from the time the firing level is reached until repolarization is about one-third complete
  • Relative refractory period, lasting from this point to the start of after-depolarization

During the absolute refractory period, no stimulus, no matter how strong, will not excite the nerve. However, during the relative refractory period, stimuli that are stronger than normal can cause excitation.

The absolute refractory period for large myelinated nerve fibers is about 1/2500 second.

questions.text: Rheobase is an indicator of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The rheobase is an indicator of the magnitude of the current. It is the minimum intensity (strength/magnitude) of stimulation required to generate an action potential when the stimulation is of infinite duration.

Utilization time is the minimum time (duration) for which the rheobase has to be applied for the excitation of tissue.

Chronaxie is the minimum time (duration) for which a stimulus double the strength of rheobase has to be applied for excitation of tissue.

Strength-duration curve gives the idea of the excitability of a tissue.

Strength-duration relationship arises because the same minimum electrical charge necessary to excite an action potential can come from a current that is either brief but large or prolonged but small. It is the product of strength and duration that determines excitability, and thus these two parameters are inversely related in their effectiveness.

Note: Chronaxie is a better index than rheobase and utilization time for comparing the excitability of a tissue.

questions.text: A slowly rising stimulus fails to fire a nerve because of a process known as __________.
questions.solution:
Slowly rising subthreshold currents fail to fire the nerve due to a process called accommodation, which is a type of adaptation.

Accommodation is due to inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels. Due to the slow rise of stimulus, only a few voltage-gated Na+ channels are activated at a time. These few channels are inactivated by the time more channels are activated. So, at no moment, are a sufficient number of channels activated to give an action potential. 

When a membrane is depolarized rapidly, a large number of Na+ channels open at once, and an action potential is produced. 

In contrast, decreased response to a long-lasting and sustained suprathreshold stimulus, in general, is called adaptation.

questions.text: In the Erlanger and Gasser classification of peripheral nerve fibers, which type of signal is transmitted by the type B nerve fibers?
questions.solution:
The type B fibers transmit the preganglionic autonomic fibers of both the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems.

Erlanger and Gasser classified the fibers into types A, B, and C, and the type A fibers are further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibers.

  • Type A fibers are the typical large- and medium-­sized myelinated fibers of spinal nerves.
  • Type B fibers are smaller fibers with minimal myelination. They transmit impulses of the ANS including the bladder. (B for Bladder)
  • Type C fibers are the small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities. They constitute more than one-half of the sensory fibers in most peripheral nerves, as well as all the postganglionic autonomic fibers.

questions.text: A man falls into a deep sleep with one arm under his head. He finds he is not able to move this arm when he awakens. However, it tingles and pain sensation in the arm is still intact. What is the reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm?

choices.text: B  fibers are more susceptible to pressure than A fibers
A fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers
C fibers are more sensitive to pressure than A fibers
Motor nerves are more affected by sleep than sensory nerves

questions.solution:
The reason for the loss of motor function without loss of pain sensation is that in the nerves to his arm, A-fibers are more sensitive to pressure than C fibers.

Sleeping for a long period with the arms under the head puts pressure on a nerve. It leads to the loss of conduction in large-diameter motor, touch, and pressure fibers, while pain sensation remains relatively intact. A-fibers (includes the motor fibers) are affected.

The susceptibility of the nerve fibers to pressure is A>B>C.

This is responsible for Saturday night or Sunday morning paralysis.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding a biphasic action potential except __________.
questions.solution:
Biphasic Action Potential

  • This type of record is obtained when both recording electrodes are placed on the surface of an axon that has been stimulated.
  • The record shows an upward deflection followed by an isoelectric interval and then a downward deflection which denotes to the time taken for the electric potential to travel from one electrode to another.

Compound Action Potential

  • It is a property of mixed nerves.
  • The record shows multiple peaks in action potential because a mixed nerve is made up of families of fibres with various speeds of conduction. Therefore, when all the fibres are stimulated, the activity in the fast-conducting fibres arrives at the recording electrode sooner than the activity in slower fibers.

questions.text: A man who is fond of exotic cuisine develops perioral numbness after eating the Pufferfish. The given poisoning is due to which of the following toxins?
questions.solution: Pufferfish poisoning is caused by the toxin tetrodotoxin. The sodium channels can be blocked by this toxin when it is applied to the outside of the cell membrane where the sodium activation gates are located.

questions.text: Conduction in the chemical synapses in CNS is
questions.solution:
Conduction in the chemical synapses in CNS is always orthodromic.

When an action potential is set up in an axon, two impulses travelling in the opposite direction is set up by depolarization on either side of the initial current. 

In the natural situation, impulses pass in one direction only- from synaptic junctions to axon terminals. Such conduction is called orthodromic. Conduction in the opposite direction is called antidromic. Under natural conditions, impulse conduction is normally only orthodromic. Antidromic conduction is usually only seen when a nerve fibre is stimulated under artificial conditions. 

In a chemical synapse, conduction is always orthodromic. As the transmission in a chemical synapse is due to the release of neurotransmitters from the presynaptic membrane which activate receptors on the postsynaptic membrane, antidromic conduction (i.e. from the postsynaptic membrane to presynaptic membrane) is not possible. Any impulse travelling in such direction would die as it encounters the first synapse.

questions.text: Fast axonal transport is by all except______
questions.solution:
Fast axonal transport is by all except neurofilaments.

Neurofilaments play no role in axonal transport. Fast axonal transport takes place along microtubules which are tubular polymers of protein tubulin. 

AXONAL TRANSPORT

  • Protein synthesis occurs in the cell body of neuron and proteins and polypeptides are transported to axonal endings by the axoplasmic flow.
  • Axonal transport can be orthograde or retrograde.
  • Orthograde transport 
    • Can be either fast or slow axonal transport and it occurs along microtubules that run along the length of the axon away from the cell body.
    • Fast axonal transport occurs at about 400 mm/day, and slow axonal transport occurs at 0.5 to 10 mm/day.
    • Molecular motor involved in orthograde transport is Kinesin.
  • Retrograde transport,
    • In the opposite direction (from the nerve ending to the cell body), occurs along microtubules at about 200 mm/day. Synaptic vesicles, nerve growth factor (NGF) and some viruses are transported back to the cell body. 
    • Molecular motor involed in retrograde transport is Dyenin.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding axonal transport?

choices.text: Slow orthograde axonal transport occurs at 100 mm/day
Kinesins are required for orthograde axonal transport
Viruses exploit retrograde transport for invasion

questions.solution:
Slow orthograde transport occurs at a speed of 0.5 to 10 mm/day.

AXONAL TRANSPORT

  • Protein synthesis occurs in the cell body of neuron and proteins and polypeptides are transported to axonal endings by the axoplasmic flow.
  • Axonal transport can be Orthograde or Retrograde.
  • Orthograde transport 
    • Can be either fast or slow axonal transport and it occurs along microtubules that run along the length of the axon away from the cell body.
    • Fast axonal transport occurs at about 400 mm/day, and slow axonal transport occurs at 0.5 to 10 mm/day.
    • Molecular motor involved in orthograde transport is kinesin.
  • Retrograde transport,
    • In the opposite direction (from the nerve ending to the cell body), occurs along microtubules at about 200 mm/day. Synaptic vesicles, nerve growth factor (NGF) and some viruses (Eg: herpes simplex, rabies, and polio) are transported back to the cell body. 
    • Molecular motor involed in retrograde transport is dyenin.

questions.text: When a nerve is cut, which of the following takes place first?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, myelin degeneration would be the best answer.

However, the earliest change in Wallerian degeneration after nerve injury is the degeneration of the axon distal to the site of injury (axonal degeneration) where there is a disruption of the retrograde and anterograde flow of signals within the axon.

Wallerian degeneration

  • If the axon is cut, the part distal to the cut degenerates; this process is called as Wallerian degeneration. 
  • Orthograde degeneration (Wallerian degeneration) occurs from the point of injury to the nerve terminal, interrupting neural transmission. 
  • After the injury, the membrane breaks down and the myelin sheath degenerates. The cell body of the injured neuron swells, the nucleus moves to an eccentric position, and the rough endoplasmic reticulum becomes fragmented (chromatolytic reaction).
  • The nerve then starts to regrow, with multiple small branches projecting along the path the axon previously followed (regenerative sprouting).
  • When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is cut and allowed to degenerate, the muscle gradually becomes extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the resting membrane potential (RMP) in a nerve fibre?

choices.text: It is equal to the RMP of inner hair cells of cochlea
It can be measured by surface electrodes
It becomes more positive as extracellular K+ increases
It depends on the equilibrium potential of Na+

questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential is close to the equilibrium potential for K+. So, changes in the external concentration of this ion can have major effects on the resting membrane potential.

  • If the extracellular level of K+ is increased (hyperkalemia), the resting potential moves closer to the threshold for eliciting an action potential, thus the neuron becomes more excitable.
  • If the extracellular level of K+ is decreased (hypokalemia), the membrane potential is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

Option a: The RMP of a nerve fiber is -70 mV, while the RMP of inner hair cells is between -45 and -60 mV relative to the fluid that bathes the basal end of the cell.

Option b: The membrane potential can be measured only when one electrode is inserted into the interior of the cell.

Option d: It depends on the equilibrium potential of K+.

questions.text: Which of the following about sensory nerve fibers is not true?
questions.solution:
Group III fibers carrying temperature, crude touch, and pricking pain sensations are δ-type A fibers, not A-gamma type .

Alternative Classification Used in Sensory Nerves

  • Group Ia. Fibers from the annulospiral endings of muscle spindles are α-type A fibers in the general classification.
  • Group Ib. Fibers from the Golgi tendon organs are also α-type A fibers.
  • Group II. Fibers from most discrete cutaneous tactile receptors and from the flower-spray endings of the muscle spindles are β- and γ-type A fibers in the general classification.
  • Group III. Fibers carrying temperature, crude touch, and pricking pain sensations are δ-type A fibers in the general classification.
  • Group IV. Unmyelinated fibers carrying pain, itch, temperature, and crude touch sensations are type C fibers in the general classification

questions.text: Absolute refractory period is due to:

choices.text: Closure of active gates of sodium channel
Closure of inactive gates of sodium channel

questions.solution:
Absolute refractory period is due to closure of inactive gates of sodium channel.

Voltage-gated sodium channels have 3 states that you can find them in. They can either be closed, open, or inactive.

When the stimulus causes activation of the open gates, sodium rushes into the cell causing the membrane potential to become more positive. After 0.5 to 1 millisecond, the inactive gate automatically closes and no stimulus, no matter how strong, can excite the nerve. This is called the absolute refractory period.

questions.text: Identify the ions A and B based on conductance graph of a neuron shown below:
questions.solution:
Channel A: Na+, Channel B: K+

Na+ channels are fast activating and are responsible for depolarization phase of action potential.

K+ channels are slow activating and open for prolonged duration than the sodium channels. They are responsible for repolarization phase of action potential. Also, the postassium channels return slowly to their closed state, which is responsible for after-hyperpolarization.

The sequence of events during the action potential occur in 7 steps as described below.

1. Resting state - Both channels are closed

2. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus. Sodium enters into the cell. The membrane reaches threshold potential.

3. The sodium influx causes opening of more sodium channels through positive feedback mechanism. Rapid depolarization occurs.

4. Sodium conductance decreases.

5. Na+ channels close and K+ channels open. Repolarization occurs.

6. Sodium channels are reset, and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus (relative refractory period). During this phase, the potassium channels remain open and slowly return to closed state causing after-hyperpolarization.

7. Both channels are closed. The membrane returns to RMP.

questions.text: The image below shows simple muscle twitch along with the time trace, recorded in a frog gastrocnemius muscle. Calculate the minimum tetanizing frequency. (The time tracer was made with a 100Hz tuning fork).
questions.solution:
The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 per second.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period. It is the frequency at which individual muscle fibres twitch that fuse and cause sustained muscle contraction, where the contraction period is the time taken from latent period to maximum force of contraction.

In this case, the time tracer was taken using a 100Hz tuning fork. Which means the tracer recorded 100 waves per second.
Therefore, the duration of each wave in time tracer = 0.01 seconds.

In the image given in the question, between the point B (end of latent period) to point C (maximum force of contraction), there are about 5 waves.
Hence, the duration of contraction = 5 x 0.01 = 0.05 seconds.

Substituting the value in the formula, we get:
Tetanizing frequency = 1/0.05 sec = 100/5 = 20/sec.

Tetanization:

The features of muscle contraction can be demonstrated by eliciting single muscle twitches. The adding together of individual twitch contractions to increase the intensity of overall muscle contraction is Summation. Summation occurs in two ways:

  • by increasing the number of motor units contracting simultaneously, which is multiple ﬁber summations.
  • by increasing the frequency of contraction, which is called frequency summation and can lead to tetanization.

When the frequency of a contraction reaches a critical level, the successive contractions eventually fuse together, and the whole muscle contraction appears to be completely smooth and continuous, this is called tetanization. Beyond this point, a further increase in the frequency, will not result in increased force of contraction.

Tetanization occurs in two ways:

  • Complete tetanus occurs when no relaxation occurs between stimuli.
  • Incomplete tetanus when periods of incomplete relaxation take place between the summated stimuli.
